sizeEntry.name: Size:
entries: Small or Medium (Depends on Species of Origin)

entries.name: Lifespan
entries: Eventides have stopped aging, although their skin might still do so. Their life usually ends by another's hand.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You have {@sense Darkvision|XPHB} with a range of 60 feet

entries.name: Undead Nature
entries: Undead Nature. Not being truly alive grants you certain benefits:

items: You don't need to eat, drink, or breathe.
You are resistant to poison damage and have advantage on saving throws against being poisoned.
You are immune to disease.
You don't require sleep and can't be magically put to sleep. To complete a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}, you must spend 6 hours in a motionless, but conscious, state.

entries.name: Death Throes
entries: Knowing how it feels to die, you know how to ignore it to keep moving on. You don't fall {@condition Prone|XPHB}, and are only considered {@condition Paralyzed|XPHB}, while making death saving throws.

Additionally, after rolling a {@variantrule Death Saving Throw|XPHB} and not dying, you can take your turn as normal, temporarily not being {@condition Paralyzed|XPHB}. Taking damage during this turn will still impose a {@variantrule Death Saving Throw|XPHB} failure.

entries.name: Eventide Legacy
entries: You are part of an eventide legacy, which grants you a specific ability. Choose a legacy from the eventide legacy table below. You gain the benefit of your chosen legacy.

entries.caption: Eventide Legacy
rows: You may use an {@variantrule Action|XPHB} to touch a creature to end one of the following conditions on them: {@condition Blinded|XPHB}, {@condition Charmed|XPHB}, {@condition Deafened|XPHB}, or {@condition Frightened|XPHB}. You can use this feature a number of times, equal to your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}, regaining all uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

Your fiendish connection allows you to bend luck to your own will. When you fail a {@variantrule D20 Test|XPHB}, you may roll a {@dice 1d4} to attempt to turn it into a success. You can use this feature a number of times, equal to your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}, regaining all uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

Your presence can instil fear. As a Magic Action, extinguish all non-magical lights in a 5-foot emanation, originating from you. All creatures of your choice in that area must succeed a Wisdom {@variantrule Saving Throw|XPHB} against 8 + your Charisma modifier + your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}, or become {@condition Frightened|XPHB} for 1 minute. They may repeat the {@variantrule Saving Throw|XPHB} at the end of their turn. You can use this feature a number of times, equal to your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}, regaining all uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

Your partial translucency allows you to more easily avoid taking {@variantrule Damage|XPHB}. When a creature, you can see within 30 feet, makes an {@variantrule Attack Roll|XPHB} against you and hits, you may use your reaction to force them to reroll it. You can use this feature a number of times, equal to your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}, regaining all uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

items.name: Flying Speed (Angelic Legacy)
entries: You gain a {@variantrule Fly Speed|XPHB}, equal to half your walking speed (rounded down).

You can use this feature a number of times, equal to your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}, regaining all uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

You can use this feature a number of times, equal to your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}, regaining all uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

entries: Your presence can instil fear. As a Magic Action, extinguish all non-magical lights in a 5-foot emanation, originating from you. All creatures of your choice in that area must succeed a Wisdom {@variantrule Saving Throw|XPHB} against 8 + your Charisma modifier + your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}, or become {@condition Frightened|XPHB} for 1 minute. They may repeat the {@variantrule Saving Throw|XPHB} at the end of their turn. You can use this feature a number of times, equal to your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}, regaining all uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

Eventides are born when a dying creature makes a deal with a psychopomp. In exchange for a longer life, they must aid the psychopomp in making other creatures move on when their time comes. However, getting life from them also means they can never truly feel like what it is to be alive, as eventides are no longer required to eat, drink, breathe, or sleep.

entries.name: Escape Death by Bringing Death
entries: An eventide is born when a creature has reached the end of their life too soon, often by the hand of others. In this moment, if the creature truly wishes to stay alive, the psychopomp bringing them to the afterlife might offer to grant that wish. In return for granting them a form of eternal life, the psychopomp shares a part of their burden with the eventide. An eventide is expected to help the psychopomp help creatures move on, whether that is by killing those who stay alive through unnatural means or by freeing spirits that have been trapped. If an eventide breaks this promise, then the psychopomp will personally end their life.

entries.name: Undead in Nature
entries: An eventide is not truly living; It is their deal with the psychopomp that keeps them in a form of undeath. Their appearance usually reflects their undead nature, often their skin will keep rotting. Additionally, eventides are always cold to the touch and their heart no longer beats. Due to their appearance, most species will instantly try to drive them away or run away themselves; Making them unwelcome in most civilisations. This behaviour is usually exaggerated because eventides are seen as harbingers of death, and most mortals don't want to be confronted by death.

entries.name: Eventide Adventurers
entries: Almost all eventides tend to be adventurers. Most simply because that is the easiest way to uphold their end of the bargain, by finding those unfortunate souls who need to move into the afterlife. Some have been forced into adventuring, due to not being welcome anywhere, due to their appearance. A small handful would be adventuring because that is the only way they can live their desired lives, while still managing to escape the wrath of the psychopomp they are betraying.

entries.name: Eventide Names
entries: Due to being created after already having had a lifetime, eventides often keep their original name. This name tends to adhere to the naming scheme that species uses. However, a select few believe that their bargain has changed them so much that they prefer to take up another name. This name is usually in the form of a title, which relates to what they are doing.

items.name: Eventide Names
entries: Black Death, Collector, Death, Deathbringer, Final Embrace, Grim Reaper, Muerta, Muerto, Soul Saviour, Ravenkeeper

entries.name: Eventide Legacies
entries: There are four different Eventide legacies, which are listed below:

items.name: Angelic Eventide
entries: An angelic eventide senses when and where a good creature has died, when they need guidance to go to the afterlife.
Angelic eventides typically have skin that remains flawless and doesn't rot and beautiful bright eyes. They also always have angelic wings. Some even have a halo.

items.name: Fiendish Eventide
entries: A fiendish eventide senses when and where an evil creature has died, when they are trying to avoid going to their afterlife.
Fiendish eventides inherit physical traits of the plane the psychopomp originates from. Typically, they get horns and dark eyes.

items.name: Reaping Eventide
entries: A reaping eventide senses when and where creatures are wrongfully prolonging their lives. They tend to hunt them down to end it for them.
Reaping eventides typically have quicker rotting skin, red glowing eyes, and their skeleton is more pronounced. Some have shadows following them, making their immediate area appear darker.

items.name: Spiritual Eventide
entries: A spiritual eventide senses when and where spirits have been wrongfully trapped. They tend to focus their efforts in freeing them, so they can move on.
Spiritual eventides typically are outlined by a white-blue glow, which makes them appear slightly translucent. Some have skin that is fully translucent, fully revealing their skeleton if not clothed.

sizeEntry.name: Size:
entries: Small or Medium (Depends on Species of Origin)

entries.name: Lifespan
entries: A genasi has the same maturity rate and lifespan as the species they originate from.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You have {@sense Darkvision|XPHB} with a range of 60 feet

entries.name: Genasi Lineage
entries: You are part of an eventide legacy, which grants you a specific ability. Choose a legacy from the eventide legacy table below. You gain the benefit of your chosen legacy.

When you reach character level 3 and 5, you learn a higher-level spell, as shown on the table. You always have that spell prepared. You can cast it once without a spell slot and regain the ability to cast it in that way when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}. You can also cast the spell using any spell slots you have of the appropriate level.

entries.caption: Genasi Lineage
rows: You can hold your breath indefinitely while you are not incapacitated. You know the {@spell Shocking Grasp|XPHB} cantrip.
Whenever you are forced to make a saving throw as a result of breathing something in, you have advantage. You know the {@spell Thaumaturgy|XPHB} cantrip.

You may throw dust into the eyes of another creature, within 10ft, as an {@action Attack|XPHB|Attack Action}. Make a ranged attack, using dexterity. On a hit the creature is {@condition Blinded|XPHB}, until the end of their next turn. You can use this feature a number of times, equal to your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}, regaining all uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}. You know the {@spell Dust Barrier|WoBrCa} cantrip.

You can move across difficult terrain without expending extra movement if you are using your walking speed on a solid surface. You know the {@spell Blade Ward|XPHB} cantrip, which you can cast using a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, a number of times equal to your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}. You regain all expended uses on a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

As a {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB}, upon being touched or hit by a melee attack within 5ft, you can deal fire damage to the creature, equal to two times your level. You can use this feature a number of times equal to your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}, regaining all expended uses on a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}. You know the {@spell Produce Flame|XPHB} cantrip.
Your vision or movement is not hindered in snow, ice, or blizzards. You know the {@spell Ray of Frost|XPHB} cantrip.
You have advantage on saving throws against being {@condition Blinded|XPHB}. You know the {@spell Starry Wisp|XPHB} cantrip
You take no damage from non-magical lava or magma, and can move through it at the same pace as your walking speed. You know the {@spell Thaumaturgy|XPHB} cantrip.
You have advantage on saving throws and ability checks to resist being {@condition Grappled|XPHB} and {@condition Restrained|XPHB}. You know the {@spell Sticky Hold|WoBrCa} cantrip.
Your {@sense Darkvision|XPHB} range increases to 120 feet. You know the {@spell Chill Touch|XPHB} cantrip.
You can see through fog, smoke, and steam as if it wasn't there. You know the {@spell Boil Fluids|WoBrCa} cantrip.

Whenever you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}, you may pick the level 1 ability from another genasi lineage (not the cantrip). Alternatively, you could roll a d12 to have it randomly change at the end of a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}. You know the {@spell Sorcerous Burst|XPHB} cantrip.
You can breathe air and water and have a swimming speed equal to your walking speed. You know the {@spell Acid Splash|XPHB} cantrip.

Genasi are the people that are most connected to the elements of air, earth, fire, light, shadow, and water. These people's temperament often reflects the element they are associated with. For instance, fire genasi tend to be quick to anger or are always raring to do stuff, while water genasi are easier going, but are often regarded as selfish.

entries.name: Children of the Elements
entries: Genasi in one way or another directly descend from the planes of elemental chaos. Whether that is because the child was born in one of those planes, because strong elemental magic was used on the unborn child, or because they directly descend from a genie, all genasi will always be connected to the elemental planes. Most genasi are aware of how they became genasi, especially those born to genasi parents, but some will live their entire lives not knowing why they are the way they are.

entries.name: Eye of the Genies
entries: Even though some mortals have been in a romantic relationship with genies, most end abruptly when the mortal is with child, as the genies often see this as an unwanted accident. This is why most genasi have never met their genie parent. However, depending on the genie type, the relationship might be different. Air genasi children, born from Djinni, are more likely to still be in contact, as those are more likely to believe it was fate the child was born. Earth genasi, born from Dao, would have been tossed aside, as soon as their parent realised that a child isn't as precious as gold and gems. Fire genasi children, from Efreeti, usually were taken away, as their mortal parent would have protected them from a life of servitude. Light genasi children, born from Pari, often seek to break contact themselves, as their parent would coddle them too much. Shadow genasi children, born from Hamzadi, would likely just have found themselves neglected by their parent. Water genasi children, born from marid, would have been discarded as their parent would have considered them a stain on noble title.

entries.name: Wild and Confident
entries: Having inherited both the clueless stupidity from mortals and single mindedness from the elemental plane, genasi tend to rarely lack confidence. A lot of genasi believe that what they intend to do is possible. Their ideas of what is possible will depend on the nature of the element they are associated with. Air genasi tend to be more accepting and go with the flow. Earth genasi are more steadfast and materialistic. Fire genasi tend to be more brash and quick to act. Light genasi tend to be kind and always willing to lend a hand. Shadow genasi tend to be more pessimistic but usually don't care if failure would hurt. Water genasi usually only think of their own benefit.

entries.name: Genasi Adventurers
entries: Genasi can have multiple reasons to want to go adventuring. Some want to discover what led to them becoming a genasi. Some would like to find their genie parent, in order to figure out why they never bothered to try to care for them. Some wish to find others of their kind, as most are born from more mundane species. Yet, others were forced into a life of adventuring, because they are seen as a curse, demon, or something similar. Since genasi tend to be uncommon, they are often shunned by the rest of the more mundane species, which causes this forced adventurer lifestyle.

entries.name: Genasi Names
entries: Genasi can inherit the naming scheme used by the mundane species they are born into or they might use their own, especially when born in a genasi community. In such a community it is common to name their children using various words related to the element they are associated with. Their last name uses the same format as the first name.

items.name: Genasi Names
entries: Ash, Boulder, Breeze, Cloud, Drip, Ember, Frost, Gravel, Mire, Mist, Mud, Rain, Rock, Silt, Snow, Sprinkle, Warmth, Wave.

entries.name: Genasi Lineages
entries: There are thirteen different genasi lineages, which are listed below:

items.name: Air Genasi
entries: As an air genasi you were either subjected to a high dose of elemental air, at or before birth, or you are descended from a djinn.
Air genasi typically have light blue skin and eyes, and often cloud-like hair. Some air genasi speak with breathy voices, marked by a faint echo.

items.name: Ash Genasi
entries: As an ash genasi you were either subjected to a high dose of both elemental air and fire, at or before birth, or your parents are an air and fire genasi.
Ash genasi typically have soot-covered skin, ember-like eyes, and black hair with ember-coloured specks. Some ash genasi speak with a very raspy voice, almost as if they are a chain smoker.

items.name: Dust Genasi
entries: As a dust genasi you were either subjected to a high dose of both elemental air and earth, or your parents are an air and earth genasi.

RDust genasi typically have skin, eyes, and hair in earthen tones. The skin of some dust genasi is very soft to the touch, and often parts flake like dust, often causing them to leave places they stay in dusty.

items.name: Earth Genasi
entries: As an earth genasi you were either subjected to a high dose of elemental earth, at or before birth, or you are descended from a dao.

Earth genasi typically have skin, eyes, and hair in earthy tones. Some might have hair that is rough to the touch or constantly covered in dust. Some also have skin that has crystalline or rocklike textures.

items.name: Fire Genasi
entries: As a fire genasi you were either subjected to a high dose of elemental fire, at or before birth, or you are descended from an efreeti.

Fire genasi typically have flaming red, coal-black, or ash-grey skin. Their eyes always seem like there is a fire lit behind them. Their hair tends to resemble fire or is sometimes actual fire, which is warm to the touch, but otherwise harmless. Some may have embers falling from their hair, when the wind picks up.

items.name: Ice Genasi
entries: As an ice genasi you were either subjected to a high dose of both air and water, at or before birth, or their parents are an air and water genasi.

Ice Genasi typically have light blue skin, light eyes, and white hair. Some ice genasi become frosted over, in normal temperatures. Usually this starts in their hair, which often allows their hair to be positioned in unnatural ways.

items.name: Light Genasi
entries: As a light genasi you were either subjected to a high dose of elemental light, at or before birth, or you are descended from a pari.
Light genasi typically have light coloured skin, eyes, and hair. The air and eyes of some light genasi appear to give off light itself.

items.name: Magma Genasi
entries: As a magma genasi you were either subjected to a high dose of both elemental earth and fire, at or before birth, or your parents are an earth and fire genasi.
Magma genasi typically have skin and hair in dark earthy tones and ember-like eyes. The skin of some magma genasi pulses with lines of, what looks like, magma, spreading around like blood vessels.

items.name: Ooze Genasi
entries: As an ooze genasi you were either subjected to a high dose of both elemental earth and water, at or before birth, or your parents are an earth and water genasi.

Ooze genasi typically have skin, hair, and eyes in sickly colours. The hair is always very fatty to the touch. Some ooze genasi always have slimy skin, often leading to leaving a layer of slime behind on doorknobs.

items.name: Shadow Genasi
entries: As a shadow genasi you were either subjected to a high dose of elemental darkness, at or before birth, or you are descended from a hamzad.
Shadow genasi typically have dark coloured skin, eyes, and hair. The eyes and hair of some shadow genasi is so black that it appears as if no light can enter it.

items.name: Steam Genasi
entries: As a steam genasi you were either subjected to a high dose of both elemental fire and water, at or before birth, or your parents are a fire and water genasi.
Steam genasi typically have skin, eyes, and hair in blue-grey tones. Their hair almost always floats upward like steam. Some steam genasi will only produce steam when they sweat or cry.

items.name: Volatile Genasi
entries: As a volatile genasi you were either subjected to a high dose of both elemental light and shadow or all elements, or you have inherited traits from all 6 pure element genasi.

A volatile genasi either looks completely normal compared to the species they originate from, or they have features of all other genasi. Some volatile genasi's traits might even change on a day-to-day basis, as these genasi are highly unpredictable.

items.name: Water Genasi
entries: As a water genasi you were either subjected to a high dose of elemental water, at or before birth, or you are descended from a marid.

Water genasi typically have dark blue or deep green skin and eyes. Their hair typically resembles water or seafoam. Some genasi always have skin that is wet to the touch and leave behind wet spots if they are in one place for too long.

sizeEntry.name: Size:
entries: Small or Medium, as they can be between 2 and 5 feet tall.

entries.name: Lifespan
entries: A genasi has the same maturity rate and lifespan as the species they originate from.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You have {@sense Darkvision|XPHB} with a range of 60 feet

entries.name: Counting Sheep
entries: When you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}, you and up to 10 creatures that rested with you gain {@variantrule Temporary Hit Points|XPHB} equal to your Wisdom modifier + proficiency bonus.

entries.name: Headbutt
entries: Whether you have a strong head or horns, you are able to deal more damage with an unarmed attack, by headbutting your opponent. Doing so deals {@damage 1d6} + Strength modifier bludgeoning damage.

entries.name: Gylangafr Lineages
entries: You are part of a gylangafr lineage, which grants you specific abilities. Choose a lineage from the gylangafr lineage table. You gain the features of your chosen lineage.

entries.caption: Gylangafr Lineage
rows: {@b Forest Leap.} Your base {@variantrule Long Jump|XPHB} is 15 feet, and your base {@variantrule High Jump|XPHB} is 10 feet, with a 10 feet running start, half as much from standstill. The rest of the jumping rule still applies, such as adding Strength (modifier) for the total distance.
{@b Nimble Step.} {@variantrule Opportunity Attack|XPHB|Opportunity Attacks} made against you are rolled with disadvantage.
{@b Sure-Footed.} You have advantage on checks and saves that knock you {@condition Prone|XPHB} or move you from your spot.
{@b Cold Resistance.} Due to living in a climate that often goes below freezing, you have become accustomed to the cold. You get resistance to cold damage.
{@b Herd Mentality.} If you are at least within 5-feet of an ally, you have advantage on Charisma, Wisdom, and Intelligence saving throws against magic.
{@b Saving the Herd.} You know the cantrip {@spell Spare the Dying|XPHB}, which you can cast at will.

items.name: Forest Leap (Forest-folk)
entries: Your base {@variantrule Long Jump|XPHB} is 15 feet, and your base {@variantrule High Jump|XPHB} is 10 feet, with a 10 feet running start, half as much from standstill. The rest of the jumping rule still applies, such as adding Strength (modifier) for the total distance.

items.name: Nimble Step (Forest-folk)
entries: {@variantrule Opportunity Attack|XPHB|Opportunity Attacks} made against you are rolled with disadvantage.

items.name: Sure-Footed (Mountain-folk)
entries: You have advantage on checks and saves that knock you {@condition Prone|XPHB} or move you from your spot.

items.name: Cold Resistance (Mountain-folk)
entries: Due to living in a climate that often goes below freezing, you have become accustomed to the cold. You get resistance to cold damage.

items.name: Herd Mentality (Plains-folk)
entries: If you are at least within 5-feet of an ally, you have advantage on Charisma, Wisdom, and Intelligence saving throws against magic.

items.name: Saving the Herd (Plains-folk)
entries: You know the cantrip {@spell Spare the Dying|XPHB}, which you can cast at will.

Gylangafr are sheep and goat people, also known as sheeple. These sheeple are most known for their want for comfort and sleep and sharing that with others. Whether they are found sleeping all day or running a tavern, it is not uncommon to find them near any place where sleep and comfort are common. It is even said that seeing too many Gylangafr in one place will make anyone fall asleep.

entries.name: Emissary or Sleep and Comfort
entries: Gylangafr are often regarded as emissaries of sleep and comfort, as it is not uncommon to find one running a tavern or selling goods that bring comfort. The establishments and goods are often of such good quality that most people staying there/using them are more than satisfied than if they go to a competitor. When a Gylangafr is unable to provide good comfort in any way, all others of that species will regard them as a failure.

entries.name: Social Communities
entries: Gylangafr are true social sheeple; they require constant socialising with others in order to stay happy. Because of this most of them can be found living in cities, big towns, or other places where lots of people gather. It is not uncommon that Gylangafr form big communities within such a place. Those who don't have other of their own species to form a community with, often take up positions where they are forced to interact with many different people, such as a tavern keeper.

entries.name: Gylangafr Adventurers
entries: Gylangafrs might go adventuring for two main reasons. The first one is that they have been shunned by their fellow sheeple, because their ability to provide comfort was nonexistent. These Gylangafr might want to seek to better their skills to prove their peers otherwise or find a community that can accept them as they are. The second reason is because they have met people that they like so much they just want to travel with them. These Gylangafr often believe that these people provide them the required comfort and socialisation needed to live a happy life.

entries.name: Gylangafr Names
entries: Gylangafr are not the most creative when it comes to naming their children. Because of this most of their names are related to the appearance or gender of their lamb. For the family name the Gylangafr often try to replicate existing human family names, but they add their own sheepish flair to it.

items.name: First Names
entries: Blackie, Ewelyn, Ewenice, Fahorn, Fleecia, Fluffo, Ramal, Rambo, Shadow, Snowy, Spots, Woollie, Yarnal.

items.name: Family Names
entries: Aram, Bewely, Cawhorn, Dewean, Ewens, Fluffharty, Glachorn, Henwool, Irramca, Keweway, Lewes, McCram, Redwool, Stallwool, Woolard, Yarnburgh.

entries.name: Gylangafr Lineages
entries: There are three different gylangafr lineages, which are listed below:

items.name: Forest-folk Gylangafr
entries: The Forest-folk are the most mysterious of the three Gylangafr subraces. They are more individual and shy than others. This often leads to them interacting with people, without those people knowing.

items.name: Mountain-folk Gylangafr
entries: The Mountain-folk are very sturdy, which they have to be in the dangerous environment they live in. Even though they still like socialising with others, they are more stubborn than other sheeple.

items.name: Plains-folk Gylangafr
entries: The Plainsfolk often form close knit communities with each other. They believe there is strength and happiness in big groups.

sizeEntry.name: Size:
entries: Small or Medium (Between 3 and 6 feet tall)

entries.name: Lifespan
entries: A kitsune lives 270 years on average, but some can live as long as 1000 years.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You have {@sense Darkvision|XPHB} with a range of 60 feet

entries.name: Shapeshifting
entries: As an {@action Magic|XPHB|Magic Action}, using somatic components, you can transform into a tiny fox form, a tailless humanoid form, of the same size as your normal form, or back to your original form. Your statistics remain the same in all forms, with these exceptions:

items: You gain a bite unarmed attack, using Strength or Dexterity, which you can use in your original and fox form.
You can't speak in the fox form.
You gain the Keen Hearing and Smell trait, while in the fox form, which gives you advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on hearing or smell.

entries.name: Kitsune Tails
entries: At level 1 you have one tail while in your original and fox form. You grow an additional tail each odd level after first, to a maximum of nine tails.

entries.name: Foxfire
entries: You can summon forth an eerie light known as foxfire in your hands, as a {@action Magic|XPHB|Magic Action}. This light gives off 20ft of dim light for 1 minute. The effect ends early when it is dispelled using {@spell Dispel Magic|XPHB} or a similar effect, dismissed by you (no action required), or by summoning another foxfire light. As part of the same action or by using another action you can make a ranged spell attack against a target within 30 feet, destroying the foxfire. On a hit the target takes {@damage 1d8} damage of the type determined by your lineage.
Choose Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma to use as your attack modifier, when you pick this species

entries.name: Higher-Level Damage
entries: The damage of this feature increases by {@damage 1d8} when you reach 5th level ({@damage 2d8}), and once again at 11th ({@damage 3d8}), and 17th ({@damage 4d8}).

entries.name: Kitsune Lineage
entries: You are part of a kitsune lineage that grants you specific kitsune abilities and a cantrip. When you choose a lineage, choose Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma to use as spellcasting ability for it. Choose a lineage from the kitsune lineages table:

entries.caption: Kitsune Lineage
rows: {@dice 1d6} + Dexterity or Strength modifier piercing damage
You learn the {@spell Earth Shaker|WoBrCa} cantrip.
{@dice 1} + Dexterity or Strength modifier piercing and {@dice 1d4} force damage
You learn the {@spell Minute Shift|WoBrCa} cantrip.
{@dice 1} + Dexterity or Strength modifier piercing and {@dice 1d4} fire damage
You learn the {@spell Control Flames|XGE} cantrip.
{@dice 1} + Dexterity or Strength modifier piercing and {@dice 1d4} acid damage
You learn the {@spell Shape Water|XGE} cantrip.
{@dice 1d6} + Dexterity or Strength modifier piercing damage
You learn the {@spell Wind Burst|WoBrCa} cantrip.
{@dice 1} + Dexterity or Strength modifier piercing and {@dice 1d4} necrotic damage
You learn the {@spell Minor Illusion|XPHB} cantrip.
{@dice 1} + Dexterity or Strength modifier piercing and {@dice 1d4} poison damage
You learn the {@spell Poison Spray|XPHB} cantrip.
{@dice 1} + Dexterity or Strength modifier piercing and {@dice 1d4} thunder damage
You learn the {@spell False Note|WoBrCa} cantrip.
{@dice 1} + Dexterity or Strength modifier piercing and {@dice 1d4} Lightning damage
You learn the {@spell Lightning Lure|TCE} cantrip.
{@dice 1d6} + Dexterity or Strength modifier piercing damage
You learn the {@spell Spectral Form|WoBrCa} cantrip.
{@dice 1} + Dexterity or Strength modifier piercing and {@dice 1d4} radiant damage
{@dice 1} + Dexterity or Strength modifier piercing and {@dice 1d4} cold damage
You learn the {@spell Wave of Protection|WoBrCa} cantrip.
{@dice 1} + Dexterity or Strength modifier piercing and {@dice 1d4} psychic damage
You learn the {@spell Fear Feed|WoBrCa} cantrip.

items.name: Kitsune Lineage (Chikyu)
entries: You are part of the chikyu kitsune lineage that grants you these specific kitsune abilities and a cantrip. When you choose a lineage, choose Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma to use as spellcasting ability for it.

items.name: Bite (Chikyu Kitsune)
entries: When you take the unarmed {@action Attack|XPHB|Attack Action}, you can instead make a bite attack, which can use Dexterity of Strength. The damage is equal to {@damage 1d6} + Dexterity or Strength modifier piercing.

Kitsunes are people who are often shrouded in mystery, but it is believed that they were once ordinary foxes who were blessed by fey. After their blessing they gained the ability to shapeshift into a humanoid form with or without fox features or back into a fox. Due to this sudden transformation most kitsune don't live in settlements of their own kind. Oftentimes they live in isolation, knowing no better, or hidden among humanoid kind.

entries.name: Many Tails
entries: As they originate from foxes, kitsunes often appear in a fox-like humanoid form. In this form the kitsune has one to nine tails, which directly relates to how powerful that kitsune is. A one-tailed kitsune might be able to use basic magic, while a nine-tailed kitsune is able to grant wishes or control nature itself. Because nine tails are seen as the ultimate form, many kitsunes strive to become as powerful as possible to eventually get to the same amount.

Even though most people believe that the power of the kitsune directly comes from their magical prowess, kitsunes are capable of growing more tails through various methods. A kitsune could spend years becoming more martially skilled or training their artisanal skills and still grow more tails.

entries.name: Nature Loving
entries: Most kitsunes come from the natural world and love it with all their heart. Because of their love kitsunes tend to only create small settlements, while using nature as part of their structure. The use of nature, the small size, and the usage of foxfire lights, these settlements look very whimsical or sometimes even a little spooky.

When not in a settlement of their own kind kitsunes tend to advocate for saving nature or actively protecting it against those who are destroying it. Oftentimes these kitsunes hide their kitsune nature when protecting the nature they so love, in hopes to prevent their species from being feared more than they already are.

entries.name: Mischievous and Helpful
entries: Things go missing around you all the time, you trip up quite often, or you see strange lights following you, a fairy or a kitsune might be having fun at your expense. Kitsunes' original fox behaviour has made them continue to love causing mischief. Most of the time this mischief is usually pretty harmless but does often land them into trouble.

On the flip side kitsunes also love to be helpful to other humanoids, provided they believe those humanoids would do them no harm. Because kitsunes love being helpful, they often take roles such as teachers or guides while living among other humanoids. Even when living in isolation many kitsune will aid a humanoid that has gotten lost or is sick or injured.

entries.name: Kitsune Adventurers
entries: There might be many reasons why kitsunes go out on their own adventures. They might have just been turned from a fox into a kitsune and wish to explore what their newly gained sentience means. They might want to leave their isolated life in a kitsune settlement and see what the world has to offer. They might even want to take revenge on a person that has destroyed a part of their homeland. In any case a kitsune adventurer tends to be cautious about showing their true form to those they meet while travelling. They intrinsically fear that the stories told about them will cause them to be chased out or harmed.

entries.name: Kitsune Names
entries: Kitsunes typically only have one name, due to living in small settlements or having just been turned into one. These names are given by their parents as a wish of in what manner they want their child to grow up as, such as Hiro (Hero) or Migoto (beautiful). Alternatively, kitsunes might quickly pick a name for themselves the first time they enter a settlement of another humanoid, often picking one aligning with that culture.

items.name: Kitsune Names
entries: Hayai, Hiro, Isha, Johin, Jozu, Kenzai, Migoto, Rida, Rippa, Saishi, Shihan, Tasai, Tsuyoi, Waizu, Yasashi, Yutaka, Yuyo.

entries.name: Kitsune Lineages
entries: There are thirteen different kitsune lineages, which are listed below:

items.name: Chikyu Kitsune
entries: Chikyu kitsunes are the kitsunes that usually look like normal foxes. However, looks can be deceiving, as these kitsunes are believed to have control over earthquakes. Angering these kitsunes can cause an entire city to be destroyed because of it, so it is in everyone's best interest to be nice to all foxes.

items.name: Jikan Kitsune
entries: Jikan kitsunes are kitsunes that are believed to have mastery over time itself. These kitsunes are rarely seen, but when they are people often feel like there is a piece of time missing or added to their memory. It is unknown if these kitsune are truly responsible for this phenomenon. These kitsune are often depicted as having white fur, with the fur on the extremities being black.

items.name: Kasai Kitsune
entries: Kasai kitsunes are the kitsunes which have mastery over fire. They use their mastery of fire to ward off evil and help people survive through the night. These kitsunes are often depicted with orange fur, which glows like fire.

items.name: Kawa Kitsune
entries: Kawa kitsunes are kitsunes that love water as much as they love land. They often settle near rivers or lakes, so they can have both land and water within reach. They tend to not have a sense of hygiene, as their time in the river cleans them often. These kitsunes are often depicted as having light green or light blue fur, which always seems to glisten as if wet. Their tails may even resemble tentacles.

items.name: Kaze Kitsune
entries: Kaze kitsunes are the kitsunes that feel connected to the element of wind itself. They tend to have an obsession with being as fast as possible. These kitsunes have fur in varying colours, but all of them have some sort of wind marking in their fur. Additionally, their fur always looks like it's flowing in the wind, even if there is none.

items.name: Kukan Kitsune
entries: Kukan kitsunes are the kitsunes that are able to manipulate space itself. Using the darkness around them, they create powerful illusions, which are almost impossible to distinguish from reality. They tend to use this power to aid others, but Kukan kitsunes also love to be mischievous. These kitsunes are often depicted as having dark purple, blue, grey, or even black fur.

items.name: Mori Kitsune
entries: Mori kitsune are kitsune which live in isolation in the forest. They often help people find their way when they have gotten lost in their forest. However, when you start destroying their home, they will surely seek revenge by poisoning your food and drink. These kitsunes are often depicted as having brown or green fur, which looks like it has moss growing on them. Their tails may even look a bit like branches or vines.

items.name: Ongaku Kitsune
entries: Ongaku kitsunes love music and song. They often become wandering bards or court musicians, to satisfy their constant need to create music. These kitsunes are depicted as having fur in various colours, but always with musical notes depicted in their fur.

items.name: Sanda Kitsune
entries: Sanda kitsunes are seen as bad omens. When they show up, a bad storm is likely to follow. However, they often try to warn and protect people of the storm it sensed coming. These kitsunes are often depicted having fur sand or yellow coloured fur, with sparks of lightning running through them.

items.name: Seishin Kitsune
entries: Seishin kitsunes, also known as "spirit foxes", are surrounded in mystery. Not much is known about them, apart from the belief that they grant wishes. Their fur is often light grey, which might even look slightly translucent under moonlight.

items.name: Tengoku Kitsune
entries: Tengoku kitsunes are seen as the kitsunes directly blessed by the heavens. These kitsunes love helping others and tend to take up positions as teachers. These kitsunes are often depicted with white fur with some red patterning on their face.

items.name: Umi Kitsune
entries: Umi kitsunes are kitsunes that live in isolation near oceans, most often oceans in colder climates. There they hone their skills to be able to heal and protect the sick and injured. Although they  tend to live in isolation, these kitsunes make sure people know where they live, when their services are required. These kitsunes are often depicted with deep blue fur.

items.name: Yama Kitsune
entries: Yama are the kitsunes feared by all. These kitsunes have been banished to live in mountains due to people believing that they need to feed on humanoid sadness and fear, which the kitsunes often cause themselves. These kitsunes are often depicted having brown fur with varying fearful symbols in their fur.

sizeEntry.name: Size:
entries: Small or Medium (Between 2 and 7 feet tall)

entries.name: Lifespan
entries: A leshy lives 50 years on average, before the spirit leaves the plant vessel.

entries.name: Plant Nourishment
entries: You don't need to eat or drink the same way another creature has to. You eat and drink when you take a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}, by absorbing nutrients from the ground using your hyphae or roots.
Once per {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}, you can spend 1 minute in direct sunlight to regain {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} equal to 2 times your level.

entries.name: Grasping Reach
entries: You extend vines, roots, or hyphae to try to restrain one creature. As an {@action Magic|XPHB|Magic Action}, you may attempt to {@condition Restrained|XPHB|restrain} one creature within 15ft, for 1 minute. That creature must succeed a Strength Saving throw against a DC equal to  8 + Dex Modifier + proficiency bonus. The {@condition Restrained|XPHB} creature can use its action to make a Strength (athletics) or Dexterity (acrobatics) check to attempt to escape. Another creature may also use a Strength (athletics) action to attempt to pull them free.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}. You regain all expended uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

entries.name: Leshy Lineage
entries: You are part of a leshy lineage that grants you a specific leshy ability. Choose a lineage from the leshy lineages table:

entries.caption: Leshy Lineage
rows: You gain an unarmed spine attack, for which you can use your Strength or Dexterity. This attack can be used as a melee or ranged (20/60) attack. The damage is {@dice 1d6} + Dexterity or Strength modifier.

Once per {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}, you can use your {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} to release pollen from your flower, after being hit. That creature has disadvantage on that attack roll and any following attack rolls, until the end of your turn.
Once per {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}, you or an ally can use their {@variantrule Action|XPHB} to pluck and eat one fruit from you. This fruit heals them equal to 2 times your level.
You gain {@sense Darkvision|XPHB} with a range of 60 feet and can use plant nourishment without needing sunlight.
Your body is so soft, you take no damage from {@hazard Falling|XPHB}, regardless of the distance. You also gain resistance to non-magical bludgeoning damage.
You can breathe underwater and gain a swimming speed equal to your walking speed.

items.name: Cactus Spines (Cactus Leshy)
entries: You gain an unarmed spine attack, for which you can use your Strength or Dexterity. This attack can be used as a melee or ranged (20/60) attack. The damage is {@damage 1d6} + Dexterity or Strength modifier.

items.name: Pollen Puff (Flowering Leshy)
entries: Once per {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}, you can use your {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} to release pollen from your flower, after being hit. That creature has disadvantage on that attack roll and any following attack rolls, until the end of your turn.

items.name: Healing Fruit (Fruit Bearing Leshy)
entries: Once per {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}, you or an ally can use their {@variantrule Action|XPHB} to pluck and eat one fruit from you. This fruit heals them equal to 2 times your level.

items.name: Deep Fungus (Fungal Leshy)
entries: You gain {@sense Darkvision|XPHB} with a range of 60 feet and can use plant nourishment without needing sunlight.

items.name: Leaf Body (Leaf Leshy)
entries: Your body is so soft, you take no damage from {@hazard Falling|XPHB}, regardless of the distance. You also gain resistance to non-magical bludgeoning damage.

items.name: Amphibious (Water Leshy)
entries: You can breathe underwater and gain a swimming speed equal to your walking speed.

Leshies are plants and fungi harbouring immortal nature spirits, who seek to experience the world first hand. As guardians and emissaries of nature and the environment leshy appear whenever a plant has grown up to be a suitable vessel. From the moment they take control of a plant a leshy is fully capable and considered an adult.

entries.name: Born a Plant, Died a Plant
entries: Before a leshy appears, a plant undergoes the normal means of growth. Only when a plant has grown to be a suitable vessel do leshy take control of it. Often leshy or druids grow and cultivate plants to become such a suitable vessel to gain a new companion, child, or friend. It is believed that each leshy gravitates to certain vessels more than others, such as preferring cacti over tree vessels.

After taking control a leshy can finally experience the world firsthand, and no longer needs to watch it from behind a hazy veil. They live in this form until they feel like they have seen everything they wanted to, after which they leave the vessel. Once they have left the vessel, the plant continues to grow as it normally would, allowing the plant and fungal vessels to return to the normal natural cycle leshy wish to protect.

entries.name: Family of Nature
entries: Since leshy do not need to age to be fully capable of doing things, they don't see birth as an important factor for a family. Instead they believe that anyone whose goals align with theirs, is considered family to them. Usually this means that all leshy living together consider themselves part of one big family. Therefore, leshy settlements don't tend to have a leadership role, as everyone considers each other as equals.

When goals don't fully align with the leshy's they might still consider you a friend, but never as family. When your goal is completely opposed to the leshy's, then the leshy will consider you as their enemy, especially if your goal requires the destruction of nature.

entries.name: Natural Settlements
entries: Trees, plant matter, and earth are all things leshy use to construct their settlements. They will never take more than they give. So, for every tree they have to cut down they will plant a new one. To leshy it is holy to use the vessel left by another leshy for the construction of their own housing. They prefer using previous vessels over naturally grown materials and will make sure that no-one but leshy kind will touch those vessels, until the time is right.

When an outsider visits a leshy settlement, they will always welcome them with open arms, provided they have been good to nature. Their sprawling settlements often leave other humanoids in awe, of how without the use of magic, they shaped nature in that way. Such as beautiful vine-bound bridges between scarlet leafed trees.

entries.name: Leshy Adventurers
entries: Leshy always wanted to experience the world first hand and maybe the settlement or the druid's house, they took control of a vessel in, isn't enough to satisfy their needs. These adventuring types may want to see how other races interact with nature and show them better ways to interact with it. They might even realise how badly they treat nature and seek to avenge nature itself.
Other leshy may simply have taken control of a vessel with no-one around them. They may just be seeking more of their own kind, so they can be part of a big family.

entries.name: Leshy Names
entries: After their first year leshy are named by their parents after their first year of life as a leshy. Their name is inspired by the appearance and behaviour of the child in that first year. Their names are structured as a set of two to four words describing that appearance and/or behaviour. Because it is often a mouthful to say their full name, the leshy choose one part of their name to be commonly used when introducing themselves.

items.name: Leshy Names
entries: Ardent Flower, Leaves on Swaying Branches, Luscious Sun Bather, Scarlet Bloom, Snowy Pine Branch, Stoic Prick, Verdant Mosaic.

entries.name: Leshi Lineages
entries: There are six different leshi lineages, which are listed below:

items.name: Cactus Leshy
entries: Cactus leshy are more accustomed to life without constant water. They live in places other leshy rarely survive, such as deserts. These leshy are easier going than other leshies.

items.name: Flowering Leshy
entries: Flowering Leshy pride themselves in their own beautiful flower, which is often found on top of their head. These leshy spend many hours a day making sure their flower looks perfect. If anyone damages it or makes it filthy, then these leshy can lash out quite badly.

items.name: Fruit Bearing Leshy
entries: Fruit bearing leshy have a constant supply of fruits and maybe even vegetables, which they use to help feed other humanoids. These leshy love seeing their produce being eaten, whether it is being used raw or cooked.

items.name: Fungal Leshy
entries: Fungal leshy are not technically plants and therefore don't require light for sustenance. These leshy prefer living underground or at night. Due to their living habits, they make good assassins or thieves

items.name: Leaf Leshy
entries: Leaf leshy are almost fully made out of leafy foliage, which makes their body very soft. Because of their soft bodies these leshy love doing daring stuff, such as climbing to high places.

items.name: Water Leshy
entries: Water Leshy are the only leshy that can survive fully soaked in water, and oftentimes even in sea water. These leshy tend to be more nomadic, letting the waves carry them to new places.

sizeEntry.name: Size:
entries: Tiny or Small (Between 6 inches and 3 feet tall)

entries.name: Lifespan
entries: A poppet doesn't age. They only die when the doll or poppet they inhabit is destroyed.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You have {@sense Darkvision|XPHB} with a range of 60 feet

entries.name: Constructed
entries: Your constructed nature gives you a remarkable fortitude, represented by the following benefits:

items: You have advantage on saving throws against being poisoned, and you have resistance against poison damage.
You can't and don't need to eat, drink, or breathe.
You are immune to disease.
You don't need to sleep, and magic can't put you to sleep.
When taking a long rest, you must remain motionless for at least six hours, during which you remain conscious.

entries.name: Inanimate Nature
entries: Not truly being alive allows you to survive more killing blows. The first time, each day, you are reduced to 0 hit points, you are instead reduced to 1 hit point, provided the effect doesn't kill you outright. You regain an expended use when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

entries.name: False Toy
entries: When you stand completely still, you are almost indistinguishable from an ordinary toy poppet. You have advantage on Dexterity (stealth) and Charisma (performance) checks to pass off as a regular toy poppet

entries.name: Poppet Build
entries: You are part of a specific poppet build that grants you a specific poppet ability. Choose a build from the poppet build table below:

entries.caption: Poppet Build
rows: Your clockwork body allows you to shift your mechanisms for other purposes. You learn the {@spell Mending|XPHB} and {@spell Prestidigitation|XPHB} cantrips. Spending 10 minutes casting {@spell Prestidigitation|XPHB}, you can transform yourself to have minor useful devices, such as a fire starter, shears, or a music box. You can have no more devices, equal to your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB| Proficiency Bonus}, active at a time. You or another creature within 5 feet of you can use a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} to use one of these devices.
Your body is so soft, you take no damage from {@hazard Falling|XPHB}, regardless of the distance. You also gain resistance to non-magical bludgeoning damage.
Your  body is very sturdy, which gives you natural armour equal to 13 + Dex modifier, when not wearing any armour. When wielding a shield, you may still apply its bonus.

items.name: Clockwork Body (Clockwork Poppet)
entries: our clockwork body allows you to shift your mechanisms for other purposes. You learn the {@spell Mending|XPHB} and {@spell Prestidigitation|XPHB} cantrips. Spending 10 minutes casting {@spell Prestidigitation|XPHB}, you can transform yourself to have minor useful devices, such as a fire starter, shears, or a music box. You can have no more devices, equal to your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB| Proficiency Bonus}, active at a time. You or another creature within 5 feet of you can use a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} to use one of these devices.

items.name: Soft Body (Stuffed Poppet)
entries: Your body is so soft, you take no damage from {@hazard Falling|XPHB}, regardless of the distance. You also gain resistance to non-magical bludgeoning damage.

items.name: Sturdy Body (Wooden Poppet)
entries: Your  body is very sturdy, which gives you natural armour equal to 13 + Dex modifier, when not wearing any armour. When wielding a shield, you may still apply its bonus.

A spark of life enters a forgotten toy in an abandoned house, creating a living poppet. Now walking, talking, and intelligent, these poppets are ready to take their first steps in life. Some might be like a baby and need time to mature, while others come into this world with mature minds. No matter how a poppet came to be, they either find themselves all alone or part of an already existing family of other humanoids.

entries.name: Spark of Life
entries: A living poppet can appear in various ways, with the most common one being the possession of a poppet by a spirit. These poppets often go through life to try to complete unfinished business the spirit might have had. Whether that is to seek justice on the person that got them killed or to tell a person how they really felt about them, these poppets go through life with purpose, so they can finally move on. However, not all possessed poppets have unfinished business, some may just not want to leave the mortal realm at all, while others might be secretly possessed by a devil or demon trying to cause harm.

The two other methods in which a poppet can come to life is through a spark of magic or a child's wish. The latter happens when a child has such strong emotions about a particular poppet or situation that the poppet comes to life to help the child fulfil the wish. Oftentimes after the child has grown up, these poppets lose purpose and try to find a new one.

entries.name: Poppet Adventurers
entries: Poppets rarely know others of their kind and may wish to set out on an adventure, in the hopes to share experiences and thoughts with someone almost exactly like them. Other poppets may be searching for a purpose after their child has grown up and doesn't need them anymore.
Possessed poppets will likely go on an adventure to try to finish their unfinished business, while others might just want to experience what the world has to offer for just that bit longer.

entries.name: Poppet Names
entries: Poppet names are very varied and usually depend on how they came to be in this world. A poppet created by magic or through a child's wish is often named by the person who created them. A possessed poppet often takes the name they had in life before possessing a poppet. All these names often follow cultural naming schemes of other species.

entries.name: Poppet Builds
entries: There are three different poppet builds, which are listed below:

items.name: Clockwork Poppet
entries: A clockwork poppet is a poppet made out of gears, wire, and hinges, in order to move all on its own, usually after being wound up. As it has gained sentience, the winding mechanism seems to rewind itself each night.

items.name: Stuffed Poppet
entries: A stuffed poppet is a poppet made fully out of cloth and stuffed with wool or something similar. These poppets tend to have buttons for eyes.

items.name: Wooden Poppet
entries: A wooden poppet is usually made to look as realistic as possible, even using humanoid or horsehair for the poppet's hair.

sizeEntry.name: Size:
entries: Small (Between 2 and 4 feet tall)

entries.name: Lifespan
entries: Ratfolk can live up to 50 years, but mature in 1 year time.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You have {@sense Darkvision|XPHB} with a range of 60 feet

entries.name: Plague Resistant
entries: You are quite resistant to plagues and similar effects, which is represented by the following benefits:

items: You have advantage on saving throws against being poisoned, and you have resistance against poison damage.
You are immune to disease.
You can eat and drink spoiled food and fluids without issue.

entries.name: Rat Insticts
entries: You are naturally good at finding your way. You gain proficiency in the {@skill Survival} skill.

entries.name: Bite
entries: You may bite a creature, as an unarmed attack. For this attack you may use your Strength or Dexterity. On a hit the target takes {@damage 1d6} + Strength or Dexterity modifier piercing damage.

entries.name: Squeeze In
entries: You are used to being in tight spaces all the time. You may end your turn in a willing ally's space. When you or the ally, you share a space with, is targeted by an attack, you share the damage. Both of you take half of the damage rolled, with the excess damage going to the original target of the attack. If there is an additional effect, only the target deals with that effect.
Additionally, when squeezing through spaces of a size smaller than you, you don't count it as difficult terrain.

Clever and adaptable are the two most common things ratfolk are often described as. They are considered clever due to almost always knowing how to survive when out travelling, whether that be in the city, ship, or out in the wilds. This is partially due to their sharp instincts, but also due to their adaptable nature. Ratfolk don't mind eating or drinking food and drink that has gone off and can easily navigate in small spaces.

entries.name: Crowded Families
entries: Ratfolk settlements are almost never very large, even though their population is almost always booming. This is because ratfolk don't mind living very crowded in a house with their entire family, which is quite often at least 20 people large. Since ratfolk prefer living in the dark, the settlement streets only tend to become as lively as inside the houses at dusk.

Ratfolk culture causes them to do almost everything together with their family. Most families will only eat meals together, which would be the only times they eat at all. Entire families will go to the shops together, even if all they need is a single loaf of bread. Even the workplaces tend to be family run, with the oldest ratfolk acting as the boss and the rest as the workers.

entries.name: Navigating the World
entries: Some ratfolk love exploration more than they love constantly spending time with their family. These ratfolk leave their homes in search of a job such as travelling guide, ship's navigator, or maybe just an adventurer. They do this because they are curious by nature and know they have better chances of survival than most other humanoids.

Most other species gladly accept ratfolk among their ranks, due to their good instincts and adaptability. However, they also know to bring their own food and drink, as their ratfolk guide may offer them spoiled food and drink.

entries.name: Ratfolk Adventurers
entries: A ratfolk may become an adventurer when they feel the calling to leave the nest to go explore. They may have heard about a specific object or place that piqued their curiosity, or they may just want to get out of their crowded family situation.

Another reason a ratfolk may become an adventurer is to help find a cure for a cursed family member or to track down the person who murdered the rest of their family. These ratfolk only become adventurers for the necessity and would love to return to their cramped life when all has been dealt with.

entries.name: Ratfolk Names
entries: Ratfolk families only use a dozen or so names that are often passed down from great grandparents to their child. Often this causes brothers and sisters to have the same name. Because of that their parents also use a descriptor word to differentiate between children. Most ratfolk think it is distasteful to be called by the descriptor word alone and either introduce themselves using both the descriptor word and given name, or the given name alone.

items.name: Ratfolk Names
entries: Armando, Barnan, Chikis, Chonan, Citlali, Dulsie, Eugenio, Hugo, Iktan, Ins, Isabel, Javier, Juan, Luis, Lucia, Malena, Olivia, Pascual, Ral, Sesai, Seti, Vicente, Ximena.

items.name: Desciptor Words
entries: Black, Blue, Bright, Brave, Clever, Curious, Cute, Daring, Dumb, Fat, Green, Grey, Idiotic, Intelligent, Pink, Pretty, Rebellious, Red, Scrawny, Smart, Strong, Weak, White, Yellow.

subclassFeature.name: Path of the Inferno
entries: Born from within the chambers of a volcano, barbarians who follow the Path of the Inferno have learned to harbour the unpredictable and forceful nature of the flame. These warriors transform their bodies into a raging and unstoppable inferno, leaving naught but destruction in their wake.
Barbarians who follow this path are often warriors who prefer to start the fight and let the fight be emotion driven. Once they have set a course, only the strongest foes can stop them.

subclassFeature.name: Firesoul
entries: Starting when you choose this path at 3rd level, your skin becomes hot to the touch. You gain resistance to fire damage and don't suffer consequences from extreme heat.

In addition to that, while you are {@classFeature Rage|Barbarian|XPHB|1|XPHB|raging}, anyone who hits you with a melee attack and is within 5ft of you, takes fire damage equal to your Barbarian level.

subclassFeature.name: Flamelash
entries: Also at 3rd level, you can unleash the hottest flames with your attacks. The first target you hit while using a {@classFeature Reckless Attack|Barbarian|XPHB|2|XPHB}, while your {@classFeature Rage|Barbarian|XPHB|1|XPHB} is active, takes extra fire damage. To determine the extra damage, roll a number of d6s, equal to your {@classFeature Rage|Barbarian|XPHB|1|XPHB} damage bonus, and add them together.

subclassFeature.name: Unstoppable Flame
entries: At 6th level, the first time you are reduced to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}, for each active {@classFeature Rage|Barbarian|XPHB|1|XPHB}, you can use your {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} to make one final {@action Attack|XPHB|Attack Action} before falling unconscious. This action  can be used to make at most 2 attacks. (If you have {@classFeature Relentless Rage|Barbarian|XPHB|11|XPHB}, you can only use this {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} after failing the {@classFeature Relentless Rage|Barbarian|XPHB|11|XPHB} saving Throw.)
In addition to that, you are immune to the {@condition Charmed|XPHB} and {@condition Frightened|XPHB} conditions while {@classFeature Rage|Barbarian|XPHB|1|XPHB|raging}.

subclassFeature.name: Fire Presence
entries: At 10th level, you always radiate a fiery presence while {@classFeature Rage|Barbarian|XPHB|1|XPHB|raging}. While your {@classFeature Rage|Barbarian|XPHB|1|XPHB} is active you can use replace your {@subclassFeature Flamelash|Barbarian||Inferno|WoBrCa|3} effect to instead burn all creatures within 10ft of you. Each creature of your choice within range must succeed a Dexterity saving throw (DC 8 + Constitution modifier + {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}) or take fire. To determine the fire damage, roll a number of d6s equal to your {@classFeature Rage|Barbarian|XPHB|1|XPHB} damage bonus, and add them together. A creature takes half damage on a successful save.

subclassFeature.name: Inferno
entries: At 14th level, you can release all that built up heat within yourself. As an {@variantrule Action|XPHB}, while {@classFeature Rage|Barbarian|XPHB|1|XPHB|raging}, you release a blazing inferno. All creatures within 20ft of you must succeed a Dexterity saving throw (DC 8 + Constitution modifier + {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}), or take {@damage 12d6} fire damage, half as much damage on a successful one. And anything that is flammable and not worn or held, is ignited.

Once you use it you can't again, until you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}, unless you expend a use of your {@classFeature Rage|Barbarian|XPHB|1|XPHB} (no action required) to restore your use of it.

subclassFeature.name: Festivity Domain
entries: The Gods of festivity–Including Lliira, Milil, Apollo, Hathor, Balder–value the fun of a whole group more than anything else. Some believe that group outings are the only way to enjoy yourself to the fullest. Some deities go down to the material plane to start their own parties to escape the boring time of the afterlife. Followers of these gods usually travel around the world to attend or give the best parties, and some stay in one place to create the best party place there is in the whole world. But above all the followers of these gods will always try to live life to the fullest and enjoy their time with others as much as they can.

subclassFeature.name: Festivity Domain Spells
entries: Your connection to this divine domain ensures you always have certain spells ready. When you reach a Cleric level specified in the Light Domain Spells table, you thereafter always have the listed spells prepared.

subclassFeature.name: Bonus Proficiency
entries: When you choose this domain at 1st level, you gain proficiency in the Charisma (Performance) skill and one musical instrument of your choice.

subclassFeature.name: Blessing of the Drunk
entries: Also at 1st level, you gain the blessing of the drunk, granting you the following benefits:

items.name: Tolerance
entries: You gain poison resistance. And if you are drunk/poisoned you don't get disadvantage on {@variantrule Attack Roll|XPHB|Attack Rolls} or {@variantrule Ability Check|XPHB|Ability Checks}.

items.name: Drunken Brawler
entries: Your unarmed attacks deal damage equal to {@damage 1d4} + Strength Modifier. In addition to that your improvised weapons can be used as a greatclub/club, with which you are considered proficient.

subclassFeature.name: Channel Divinity: Song of Inspiration
entries: Starting at 2nd level, you can use channel divinity to make your voice more beautiful than ever, which will inspire your allies.

As an {@variantrule Action|XPHB} you can hold out your holy symbol and sing an inspiring short song. As a magic action you can hold out your holy symbol and sing an inspiring short song. Any creature of your choice, within 30 feet, may add 1d6 to one {@variantrule D20 Test|XPHB}, within the next 10 minutes. They may add this 1d6 after they know the result, potentially turning a failure into a success.

subclassFeature.name: Festivity Domain
entries: The Gods of festivity–Including Lliira, Milil, Apollo, Hathor, Balder–value the fun of a whole group more than anything else. Some believe that group outings are the only way to enjoy yourself to the fullest. Some deities go down to the material plane to start their own parties to escape the boring time of the afterlife. Followers of these gods usually travel around the world to attend or give the best parties, and some stay in one place to create the best party place there is in the whole world. But above all the followers of these gods will always try to live life to the fullest and enjoy their time with others as much as they can.

subclassFeature.name: Festivity Domain Spells
entries: Your connection to this divine domain ensures you always have certain spells ready. When you reach a Cleric level specified in the Light Domain Spells table, you thereafter always have the listed spells prepared.

subclassFeature.name: Blessing of the Drunk
entries: Starting at 3rd level, you gain the blessing of the drunk, granting you the following benefits:

items.name: Tolerance
entries: You gain poison resistance. And if you are drunk/poisoned you don't get disadvantage on {@variantrule Attack Roll|XPHB|Attack Rolls} or {@variantrule Ability Check|XPHB|Ability Checks}.

items.name: Drunken Brawler
entries: Your unarmed attacks deal damage equal to {@damage 1d4} + Strength Modifier. In addition to that your improvised weapons can be used as a greatclub/club, with which you are considered proficient.

items.name: Musician
entries: You become proficient with one musical instrument of your choice and in the Charisma (performance) skill.

subclassFeature.name: Song of Inspiration
entries: Also at 3rd level, you can use a charge of your channel divinity to make your voice more beautiful than ever, which will inspire your allies.

As an {@variantrule Action|XPHB} you can hold out your holy symbol and sing an inspiring short song. As a magic action you can hold out your holy symbol and sing an inspiring short song. Any creature of your choice, within 30 feet, may add 1d6 to one {@variantrule D20 Test|XPHB}, within the next 10 minutes. They may add this 1d6 after they know the result, potentially turning a failure into a success.

subclassFeature.name: Dancing Defence
entries: Starting at 6th level, you can use your movement to dance until the start of your next turn, instead of moving. The dance gives anyone that attacks you disadvantage on their attack rolls, and you have advantage on Dexterity saving throws.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of 1), regaining all uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

subclassFeature.name: Divine Strike
entries: At 8th level, you gain the ability to infuse your weapon and unarmed strikes with divine energy. Once on each of your turns when you hit a creature with a weapon attack, you can cause the attack to deal an extra {@damage 1d8} acid or poison damage (your choice) to the target.
When you reach 14th level, the extra damage increases to {@dice 2d8}.

subclassFeature.name: Improved Divine Strike
entries: At 14th level, the extra damage from Divine Strike increases to {@damage 2d8} acid damage.

subclassFeature.name: Pop-up Party
entries: Starting at 17th level, you can use your {@variantrule Action|XPHB} to start an illusionary party that lasts for 1 minute or until you dismiss it (no action required). Within 30 feet of you, your enemies take an additional 2d10 thunder damage the first time they take damage on a turn. Additionally, enemies have disadvantage on Wisdom (perception) checks while in this area.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your wisdom modifier (minimum of 1), regaining all uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

subclassFeature.name: Field Medic
entries: Certain Fighters specialise more in the welfare of their fellow combatants. These fighters have been trained to use a healer's kit to the best of their abilities, while actively involved in combat.

subclassFeature.name: Medic
entries: When you choose this archetype at level 3, you gain expertise in the Wisdom (medicine) skill if you don't have it already.

subclassFeature.name: Healer
entries: Also at 3rd level, you can heal damaged creatures, granting you the following benefits:

subclassFeature.name: Healer Points
entries: You gain 3 healer points, which can be expended on various patch ups. You regain all healer points on a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}. You gain 1 more healer point for each time you level up your fighter class.

subclassFeature.name: Patch Ups
entries: You choose three Patch Ups of your choice and can choose two more additional Patch Ups of your choice when you reach fighter level 7, 10, and 15. All patch ups can be used as a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}.
Additionally, each time you gain a level, you may exchange one Patch Up for another.

subclassFeature.name: Healer's Kit Usage
entries: Each {@subclassFeature Patch Ups|Fighter|PHB|Medic|WoBrCa|3||Patch Up} uses the Healer's Kit. However, it will not use up one of its charges. If a Healer's Kit has no more charges left, it cannot be used for the {@subclassFeature Patch Ups|Fighter|PHB|Medic|WoBrCa|3}.

subclassFeature.name: Patch Up Options
entries: The Patch Ups are presented in alphabetical order:

subclassFeature.name: Preserver of Life
entries: Starting at 7th level, you know how to prevent an ally from dying better than anyone else. You can use a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} to stabilise a creature using a Healer's Kit or a medicine check.
Additionally, when you stabilise a creature using an {@variantrule Action|XPHB}, they regain 1 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB|Hit Point}.

subclassFeature.name: Battle Healer
entries: Starting at 10th level, you are able use your {@subclassFeature Patch Ups|Fighter|PHB|Medic|WoBrCa|3} abilities as part of your attacks. Whenever you make the {@action Attack|XPHB|Attack Action}, you can replace one of your attacks with a {@subclassFeature Patch Ups|Fighter|PHB|Medic|WoBrCa|3||Patch Up} feature.
Additionally, whenever you allow another creature to reattempt a saving throw with a patch up feature, they can add your Wisdom modifier to that saving throw result.

subclassFeature.name: Mass Healer
entries: Starting at 15th level, you can use your action to expend all remaining charges of a Healer's Kit to restore {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} to one creature you can touch. For each charge used you can restore {@dice 1d12} {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}.
Once you use this feature, you cannot do so until you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

subclassFeature.name: True Field Medic
entries: Starting at 18th level, you regain 5 spent {@subclassFeature Healer Points|Fighter|PHB|Medic|WoBrCa|3} whenever you roll {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB}.

subclassFeature.name: Stone Warrior
entries: Fighters who choose this Archetype are usually people who prefer taking blows over dealing them. They are hardy and stubborn, and trying to move them out of the way causes problems.

subclassFeature.name: Strength of the Boulder
entries: Beginning when you choose this archetype at 3rd level, you get {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB} in the {@skill Athletics|XPHB} skill, if you didn't have it already. You can use double your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus} for it.
In addition to that, you count as one size larger when determining your carry capacity.

subclassFeature.name: Stubborn Defiance
entries: Also, at 3rd level, you are so stubborn that your mind can't be altered so easily. You gain advantage on saves against being {@condition Frightened|XPHB} and {@condition Charmed|XPHB}.

subclassFeature.name: Stone Endurance
entries: Also, at 3rd level, you become much hardier. You gain 2 additional {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} for each level you have in the Fighter Class.
In addition to that you gain resistance to poison damage and advantage on saving throws against being {@condition Poisoned}.

subclassFeature.name: Stoneskin
entries: Starting at 7th level, your skin is hard as rock. You gain resistance to non-magical bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage, and you become immune to poison damage and the {@condition Poisoned|XPHB} and {@condition Petrified|XPHB} conditions.

subclassFeature.name: Grounded
entries: Starting at 10th level, you cannot be moved against your will, provided you are not unconscious. Any effect that would move you from your place or knock you {@condition Prone|XPHB} doesn't affect you.

subclassFeature.name: One with the Ground
entries: Starting at 15th level, you get 15 feet of {@sense Tremorsense|XPHB}.

Additionally, when you are standing on a solid surface and a grounded creature makes an attack roll, against you or an ally, within 5 feet of you, you may make an attack roll against them as a {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB}.

subclassFeature.name: Ground Shaker
entries: Starting at 18th level, you can stomp on the ground so hard that it causes a localised earthquake. As an {@variantrule Action|XPHB} you can cause an earthquake around you. Any creature within 30 feet of you, must succeed a Strength saving throw (DC, equal to 8 + your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus} + your Strength modifier), or take {@damage 10d8} bludgeoning damage and be knocked {@condition Prone|XPHB}, half as much on a successful one. Structures within 30 feet of you take {@damage 50} bludgeoning damage.
You can use this feature once, regaining the use on a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB|short} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

subclassFeature.name: Oath of the Nomad
entries: The Oath of the Nomad binds a paladin to a life on the road. Sometimes they are called pilgrims, crusaders, wandering sellswords, or just nomads. Even though they may commit acts other paladins abhor, they usually do it to help someone who required aid. Many who swear to this oath are bound by neutrality, as one cannot be considered good or evil in all the different cultures. Because of this they prefer not to wear clothing or use symbols associated with a specific culture.

subclassFeature.name: Oath of the Nomad
entries: The Oath of the Nomad binds a paladin to a life on the road. Sometimes they are called pilgrims, crusaders, wandering sellswords, or just nomads. Even though they may commit acts other paladins abhor, they usually do it to help someone who required aid. Many who swear to this oath are bound by neutrality, as one cannot be considered good or evil in all the different cultures. Because of this they prefer not to wear clothing or use symbols associated with a specific culture.

subclassFeature.name: Tenets of the Nomad
entries: The tenets of the Oath of the Nomad are based on a life of travel. The Oath emphasises that sharing what you have on your travels is the most sacred thing you can do. Its four central principles are as follows:

items.name: Lend Your Ear
entries: Hear out anyone who may want to be heard. Their story might inspire you to help them or others.

items.name: Lend Your Voice
entries: Share your knowledge with whomever may want to hear it. The more the people know, the more they can do to better everything around them.

items.name: Lend Your Sight
entries: Try to spot the flaws and benefits in someone else's designs and culture. This may guide you or others in the right direction.

items.name: Lend Your Ear
entries: Give a hand to someone in need. They will appreciate it and may even reward you with new stories or knowledge.

subclassFeature.name: Oath Spells
entries: You gain the following Oath spells, when you reach the listed paladin level. You always have these spells prepared, and they don't count to the maximum number of spells you can prepare.

subclassFeature.name: Oath Spells
entries: You gain the following Oath spells, when you reach the listed paladin level. You always have these spells prepared, and they don't count to the maximum number of spells you can prepare.

subclassFeature.name: Channel Divinity: Forgotten Knowledge
